name: Secobarbital
summary: Secobarbital (Seconal) is a short-acting barbiturate used for short-term treatment of insomnia and for preoperative sedation.
description: Secobarbital, marketed as Seconal, is a short-acting barbiturate sedative-hypnotic. It enhances inhibitory neurotransmission via positive allosteric modulation of GABA-A receptors, leading to CNS depression. It is indicated for short-term management of insomnia and as a preanesthetic sedative. Due to risks of tolerance, dependence, misuse, and respiratory depression, use is limited and closely monitored.

off_label_uses: None commonly recommended due to safety profile
contraindications: Acute intermittent or variant porphyria (history of manifest or latent porphyria)
Significant respiratory disease with dyspnea or airway obstruction
monitoring_required: Level of sedation and respiratory status
Signs of misuse, abuse, or dependence
Blood pressure and heart rate (perioperative use)
Fall risk, particularly in older adults

sections.text: Positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors that increases chloride ion influx, producing CNS depression; clinically results in sedation and hypnosis.

adult.oral: Insomnia: 100 mg at bedtime. Preoperative sedation: 200–300 mg once, 1–2 hours before surgery.

pediatric.oral: Preoperative sedation: 2–6 mg/kg once, 1–2 hours before surgery (maximum 100 mg/dose).

sections.text: Rapid onset with short duration of hypnotic effect; typically intended for single-dose bedtime use for insomnia or single preoperative dosing.

other: HIGH RISK OF RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION and overdose, especially with alcohol, opioids, benzodiazepines, or other CNS depressants
May cause tolerance, dependence, and withdrawal; restrict to short-term use
Contraindicated in porphyria; may precipitate an attack
Use with caution in hepatic impairment and in older adults (fall and cognitive risks)
Use during pregnancy may cause fetal harm and neonatal withdrawal

items.with: Alcohol, benzodiazepines, opioids, other CNS depressants

items.risk: Reduced anticoagulant effect due to hepatic enzyme induction
items.action: Avoid or monitor INR and adjust dose

items.risk: Decreased efficacy due to enzyme induction

items.with: CYP-metabolized medications (e.g., some antidepressants, antipsychotics, immunosuppressants)
items.risk: Altered levels due to enzyme induction
items.action: Monitor and adjust therapy as needed

items: Sedation level and respiratory status after dosing
Misuse/abuse, tolerance, and withdrawal symptoms with repeated use
Fall risk and cognitive effects in older adults

sections.pregnancy: Barbiturates cross the placenta; prolonged use may cause fetal harm and neonatal withdrawal—avoid unless benefits outweigh risks.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infants for sedation and poor feeding if use is unavoidable.
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity and fall risk; use reduced doses and caution.

sections.text: For repeated use, avoid abrupt discontinuation; taper gradually under medical supervision to reduce withdrawal risk.

items: Schedule II controlled substance (U.S.); prescribe minimal effective quantity
Reserve for short-term insomnia when alternatives fail; reassess if insomnia persists beyond 7–10 days
Paradoxical excitement may occur in older adults or debilitated patients
